case_name: Employers Association of Northern India, Kanpur v. Workmen

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 157 of 1959 appealed from judgment and decree dated January 5, 1956 of Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 205 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE, JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 157 of 1959. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated January 5, 1956, of the Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 205 of 1954 and Civil Appeal No. 158 of 1959.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 158 of 1959 by special leave from judgment and order dated January 15, 1952 of Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Allahabad in Appeal No. Cal. 47 of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 15, 1952, of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Allahabad, in Appeal No. Cal. 47 of 1951.

facts.text: Employers Association of Northern India, Kanpur made application on behalf of J. K. Cotton and Weaving Mills Co., Ltd. for termination of service of Watch and Ward Staff.

anchor.surface_text: application made by the Employers Association of Northern India, Kanpur on behalf of , the J. Cotton and Weaving Mills Co., Ltd., a member of the Association in companynection with the proposed termination of service of certain members of its Watch and Ward Staff.

facts.text: Number of thefts of Dhoties took place in the J. K. Cotton Spinning and Weaving Mills Co., Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: The application after stating that a number of thefts of Dhoties had taken place in the Mill further stated that it was obvious to the management of the J. K. Cotton Spinning and Weaving Mills Co., Ltd., that this state of affairs companyld number exist

facts.text: Management of J. K. Cotton and Weaving Mills lost confidence in honesty of Watch and Ward Staff.

anchor.surface_text: and companytinue if Watch and Ward staff were carrying out their duties vigilantly, companyrectly and honestly. It stated further that the management having lost companyfidence in the honesty of the Watch and Ward Staff had decided to terminate the services of all the per. sons of the Watch and Ward Staff

facts.text: Management decided to terminate services of all Watch and Ward Staff and recruit fresh men from employment exchange, paying 12 days wages per Standing Order No. 17A.

anchor.surface_text: had decided to terminate the services of all the per. sons of the Watch and Ward Staff and to recruit fresh men from the employment exchange and that in lieu of numberice of termination of service the management would pay to these persons 12 days wages in accordance with Standing Order No. 17A.

facts.text: Application under clause 5(a) of Government order dated March 10, 1948 amended May 15, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: The application of the Employers Association purported to be under clause 5 a  of the Government order dated March 10, 1948, as amended by a later order of May 15, 1948.

facts.text: Application made on June 13, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdispute that on June 13, 1950 when the application under clause 5 a  was made an inquiry was in fact pending before a Conciliation Officer.

facts.text: During pendency, applicant withdrew prayer as regards 5 workmen.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of the application before the Board the applicant withdrew its prayer as regards 5 of the workmen.

facts.text: Board rejected preliminary objection on jurisdiction, permitted termination of 27 sepoys with compensation.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the remaining workmen, after rejecting the preliminary objection raised on their behalf that the Board had numberjurisdiction to entertain the application, the Board held that it would number be in the interests of either party or in the interest of industry to allow the remaining 27 sepoys to companytinue in the employment of the Mills and the Board accordingly made the award permitting the appellants to terminate the services of these 27 sepoys after giving them companypensation

facts.text: Both parties appealed to Industrial Court.

anchor.surface_text: Against this order both the parties appealed to the Industrial Court.

facts.text: Industrial Court agreed on jurisdiction but found procedure defective, upheld merits, directed termination per Standing Orders without extra compensation.

anchor.surface_text: That companyrt agreed with Boards companyclusion on the question of jurisdiction but pointed out that the procedure adopted by the employers association was defective inasmuch as the mills did number apply to the Regional Conciliation Officer to discharge the sepoys in question. On merits the companyrt held that the evidence justified the companyclusion of the Board that the management had lost companyfidence in the members of the Watch and Ward Staff and that having regard to the Standing Orders their services should be terminated in accordance with the Standing Orders.

facts.text: Workmen appealed to Labour Appellate Tribunal, which held application not maintainable, set aside awards.

anchor.surface_text: The workmen then appealed to the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India. The appellate tribunal held relying on an earlier decision of its own in Kanpur Mill Mazdoor Union Employers Association of Northern India  1  that the application under cl. 5 a  of the Government Order was number maintainable. Accordingly it allowed the appeal and set aside the award of the Board as well as the Industrial Court.

facts.text: Company filed Art. 226 application to Allahabad High Court for certiorari.

anchor.surface_text: K. Cotton and Weaving Mills Co., Ltd., thereupon filed an application under Art. 226 of the Constitution to the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad praying for a writ in the nature of certiorari calling for the records of the case from the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India and quashing the order of the Tribunal which has been mentioned above.

facts.text: Mr. Justice Chaturvedi held application maintainable but dismissed for undue delay.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Justice Chaturvedi, before whom this application came up for hearing held that the application under  1  1952  1 L.L.J. 195. cl. 5 a  was maintainable and the Appellate Tribunal had erred in holding otherwise. Being however, of opinion that there had been undue delay in making this application for a writ, he dismissed the petition on that ground.

facts.text: Letters Patent appeal dismissed on preliminary objection that records in Calcutta beyond reach.

anchor.surface_text: In the Letters Patent appeal preferred by the companypany against this decision a preliminary objection was raised on behalf of the Union representing the workmen that the Allahabad High Court companyld number call for the records and quash the order of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India as those records were in Calcutta and companysequently beyond the reach of the Court. The learned Judges who heard the appeal upheld this objection and dismissed the appeal.

facts.text: High Court issued certificate under Art. 132 and 133(1)(c).

anchor.surface_text: They however issued a certificate under Art. 132 1 and Art. 133 1  c  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Special leave granted by Supreme Court for direct appeal against LAT order.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafterthe companypany also obtained special leave from this companyrt to appeal directly against the order of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India.

facts.text: Inquiry pending before Conciliation Officer on June 13, 1950 from order dated July 9, 1949 regarding dispute with S. N. Shukla.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that on July 9, 1949 the Governor of the United Provinces made an order directing the Labour Commissioner of the United Provinces or a Conciliation Officer numberinated by him in this behalf to redstart the adjudication proceedings between the J. K. Cotton Weaving Mills Co., and S. N. Shukla, a dismissed employee of the companycern.

facts.text: Time for adjudication extended to November 15, 1949; March 31, 1950; June 30, 1950; September 30, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The Adjudica- tor was directed to companyclude the adjudication and submit his award by August 15,1949. The time was extended by subsequent orders-first to November 15, 1949 and then to March 31, 1950, again to June 30, 1950 and thereafter to September 30, 1950.

facts.text: Extensions invalid but validated by s.3 U.P. Act XXIII of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that at the time these orders extending time for submission of award were made the Governor had numberauthority to make these orders and these orders were invalid. They were validated by the provisions of s. 3 of the U.P. Act XXIII of 1953.

facts.text: Supreme Court held application under cl.5(a) not maintainable due to pending inquiry under cl.23.

anchor.surface_text: As in the present case an inquiry was in fact pending before a Conciliation Officer, cl. 23 applied in respect of any discharge or dismissal of a workman and the employer companyld number take advantage of cl. 5 a  of the Government Order and such an application companyld number in law be entertained by the Board.

facts.text: Both appeals dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: Both the appeals are accordingly dismissed with companyts to the companytesting respondent.

Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 15, 1952, of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Allahabad, in Appeal No. Cal. 47 of 1951. C. Setalvad, Attorney-General for India and G. C. Mathur, for the appellant.

Thereafterthe companyany also obtained special leave from this companyrt to appeal directly against the order of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India. These two appeals preferred -one on the certificate granted by theHigh Court and the other on the strength of the special leave granted by this Court, have been heard together. The main companytroversy, as already indicated, is on the question of the maintainability of the application under cl. 5 a  of the Government order.

issues.text: the question of the maintainability of an application made by the Employers Association of Northern India, Kanpur on behalf of the J. K. Cotton and Weaving Mills Co., Ltd., a member of the Association in connection with the proposed termination of service of certain members of its Watch and Ward Staff

anchor.surface_text: These two appeals raise the question of the maintainability of an application made by the Employers Association of Northern India, Kanpur on behalf of , the J. Cotton and Weaving Mills Co., Ltd., a member of the Association in connection with the proposed termination of service of certain members of its Watch and Ward Staff. But before we come to the consideration of this question it is necessary to indicate in brief the long and tortuous path this matter has traveled before coming to us.

issues.text: the question of the maintainability of the application under cl. 5 a of the Government order

anchor.surface_text: The main controversy, as already indicated, is on the question of the maintainability of the application under cl. 5 a  of the Government order. This order issued by the Governor of the United Provinces in exercise of the powers conferred on him by the U. P. Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 contains detailed provisions as regards the settlement of industrial disputes. The first clause provides for the constitution of Conciliation Boards consisting of three members.

issues.text: whether an industrial dispute comes into existence as soon as an employer decides on the dismissal of some of the workmen and proposes to give effect to such decision

anchor.surface_text: In deciding whether an application under cl. 5 a was maintainable in the facts of the present case two questions arise for consideration. The first is whether an industrial dispute comes into existence as soon as an employer decides on the dismissal of some of the workmen and proposes to give effect to such decision. One view is that it is only the party aggrieved by the proposed dismissal, in other words, the workmen, who by objecting to the same can raise the dispute and that the employer cannot by his own proposal to dismiss the workmen be heard to say that a dispute had come into existence even before the workmen had a chance to object to the dismissal.

issues.text: whether the provisions of cl. 23 of the order bar an application under cl. 5 a during the continuance of any enquiry before the Regional Conciliation Board or the Additional Conciliation Board or during the pendency of the appeal before the Industrial Court

anchor.surface_text: The other question is whether the provisions of cl. 23 of the order bar an application under cl. 5 a during the continuance of any enquiry before the Regional Conciliation Board or the Additional Conciliation Board or during the pendency of the appeal before the Industrial Court. There is no dispute that on June 13, 1950 when the application under clause 5 a was made an inquiry was in fact pending before a Conciliation Officer.

issues.text: whether in spite of this provision in cl. 23 the employer could make and the Board entertain an application under cl. 5 a on this question of proposed dismissal
the question whether the High Court was right in its view as regards the preliminary objection

arguments.court_reasoning: LAT set aside relying on precedent; SC upheld LAT

holdings.text: cl. 5 a has no application in a case where the special provisions of cl. 23 are applicable.

anchor.surface_text: Applying this rule of construction that in cases of conflict between a specific provision and a general provision the specific provision prevails over the general provision and the general provision applies only to such cases which are not covered by the special provision, we must hold that cl. 5 a has no application in a case where the special provisions of cl. 23 are applicable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: General provisions yield to special provisions; harmonious construction requires giving effect to cl.23 without rendering it a dead letter; supported by precedents like Pretty v. Solly.

holdings.text: As in the present case an inquiry was in fact pending before a Conciliation Officer, cl. 23 applied in respect of any discharge or dismissal of a workman and the employer could not take advantage of cl. 5 a of the Government Order and such an application could not in law be entertained by the Board.

anchor.surface_text: As in the present case an inquiry was in fact pending before a Conciliation Officer, cl. 23 applied in respect of any discharge or dismissal of a workman and the employer could not take advantage of cl. 5 a of the Government Order and such an application could not in law be entertained by the Board.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inquiry pending on application date (June 13, 1950) per validated orders; cl.23 bars discharge/dismissal without permission, preventing circumvention via cl.5(a).

holdings.text: On the above conclusions we hold that the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India rightly held that the application under cl. 5 a filed on June 13, 1950 was not maintainable and rightly set aside the awards of the Conciliation Board and the Industrial Court.

anchor.surface_text: On the above conclusions we hold that the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India rightly held that the application under cl. 5 a filed on June 13, 1950 was not maintainable and rightly set aside the awards of the Conciliation Board and the Industrial Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of cl.23 over cl.5(a) confirms LAT's conclusion on maintainability despite its reliance on prior decision.

holdings.text: In view of our conclusion that the application under cl. 5 a was not maintainable, the appellant was on merits not entitled to any writ and on that ground the appeal against the High Courts order must also be dismissed.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Merits failure due to non-maintainability renders writ unavailable, independent of jurisdictional objection.

precedents.citation: Kanpur Mill Mazdoor Union Employers Association of Northern India 1

anchor.surface_text: The appellate tribunal held relying on an earlier decision of its own in Kanpur Mill Mazdoor Union Employers Association of Northern India 1 that the application under cl. 5 a of the Government Order was number maintainable. Accordingly it allowed the appeal and set aside the award of the Board as well as the Industrial Court. K. Cotton and Weaving Mills Co., Ltd., thereupon filed an application under Art. 226 of the Constitution to the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad praying for a writ in the nature of certiorari calling for the records of the case from the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India and quashing the order of the Tribunal which has been mentioned above.

precedents.cited_proposition: application under cl. 5 a of the Government Order was not maintainable

anchor.surface_text: In Pretty v. Solly 1 quoted in Craies on Statute Law at p. 205, 5th Edition Romilly, M.R. mentioned the rule thusThe rule is, that whenever there is a particular enactment and a general enactment in the same statute and the latter, taken in its most companyprehensive sense, would overrule the former, the particular enactment must be operative, and the general enactment must be taken to affect only the other parts of the statute to which it may properly apply.

precedents.cited_proposition: rule that a particular enactment prevails over a general enactment in the same statute
precedents.cited_holding: The rule is, that whenever there is a particular enactment and a general enactment in the same statute and the latter, taken in its most companyprehensive sense, would overrule the former, the particular enactment must be operative, and the general enactment must be taken to affect only the other parts of the statute to which it may properly apply.

anchor.surface_text: The rule has been applied as between different provisions of the same statute in numerous cases some of which only need be mentioned De Winton v. Brecon 1 , Churchill v. Crease 2 , United States v. Chase 3 and Carroll v. Greenwich Ins. CO. 4 . Applying this rule of companystruction that in cases of companyflict between a specific provision and a general provision the specific provision prevails over the general provision and the general provision applies only to such cases which are number companyered by the special provision, we must hold that cl. 5 a has numberapplication in a case where the special provisions of cl. 23 are applicable.

In view of this companyclusion it is unnecessary for us to companysider the other question that was raised, viz., whether an industrial dispute within the meaning of cl. 5 a companyes into existence as soon as an employer decides on the dismissal of some of its workmen and proposes to give effect to such a decision.
